title: Nine sells radio empire for $56 million
text:
Nine Entertainment has sold its broadcast radio assets, including the top-rating talkback stations 2GB and 3AW, to Australian publican Arthur Laundy and his family for $56 million.

The sale, which includes 2GB, 3AW, 4BC, 6PR, 2UE, Magic1278 and 4BH, was announced to shareholders this morning among a number of changes to the media giant's strategy which also include acquiring outdoor media platform QMS Media for $850 million.

Nine, which is the publisher of this website, told shareholders that the sale to the Laundy Family Office is expected to be completed by the end of June this year and that Nine will remain a long-term partner of the radio stations.

R EAD MORE: ﻿ Australian government 'monitoring' Nipah virus closely

Publican Arthur Laundy and his family are purchasing the Nine Radio business. (Photo: Peter Rae/AFR) (Peter Rae)

"Laundy is expected to remain a long-term partner of Nine, with plans to utilise Nine News journalists on radio, showcase Stan Sport through Laundy venues, provide promotion and advertising sales collaboration, as well as increased advertising spend by Laundy on Nine properties," the release reads.

Nine this morning also announced it was buying leading digital ﻿outdoor media platform, QMS Media and converting regional television station NBN (Northern NSW) from a wholly-owned business to an affiliate, owned and operated by Nine's regional partner, WIN Network.

Nine Group chief executive officer Matt Stanton says the move positions the media giant well for the future.

"Today's announcements mark a critical milestone in our Nine2028 transformation. These transactions will create a more efficient, higher-growth, and digitally powered Nine Group for our consumers, advertisers, shareholders and people," he said.

"This positions Nine well for the future, enabling the group to withstand industry disruption and deliver long-term sustainable value to our shareholders."

READ MORE: ﻿ How Australian spy base could play role in US strike on Iran

The sale, which includes 2GB, 3AW, 4BC, 6PR, 2UE, Magic1278 and 4BH, was announced to shareholders this morning. (Janie Barrett)

title: Elon Musk is betting Tesla's future isn't about cars at all
text:
Tesla dominated the electric vehicle industry by the mid-2010s with sleek, fast cars that helped combat the public perception that EVs were severely limited by short ranges.

Now the company, and its controversial Chief Executive, Elon Musk , face stiffer competition and political headwinds.

Its EV sales fell by a record 9 per cent in 2025, amid increasing rivalry from China and the expiration of the US EV sales tax credit.

In November last year, Elon Musk offered a sneak peak of Tesla's Optimus robot. (Tesla Australia)

But Musk has been steering the company toward an audacious bet.

He believes Tesla's future won't ride on cars but on humanoid robots.

On Tesla's earnings call on Wednesday, Musk laid out a literal replacement of Tesla cars by robots – announcing Tesla would discontinue the Model S and Model X in favour of making more of its Optimus robots.

"We're gonna take the Model S and X production space in our Fremont factory and convert that into an Optimus factory, with the long-term goal of having one million units a year of Optimus robots in the current SX space in Fremont," he said.

It is the quintessential science-fiction dream of the future: Musk says Tesla's Optimus robots will do everything from cleaning your house to performing surgery.

He's called Optimus, the key to eliminating world poverty, making human work optional and reaching Mars .

And he claims they'll be on sale by the end of 2027.

"Every human on earth is going to have their own personal R2-D2, C3PO," Musk said in November, referring to the personal robots from Star Wars .

"But actually, Optimus will be better than that."

But critics say these are fever-dream distractions from Tesla's core automotive business.

And plenty of companies, like Boston Dynamics and Figure, are already deep into the humanoid robot business.

Musk's own success and pay are directly at stake.

Tesla must deliver one million Optimus robots within 10 years for Musk to fully realise an almost $US1 trillion ($1.4 trillion) Tesla pay plan approved by shareholders late last year.

"Elon is a big thinker, and he wants to be pushing the edge of people's imagination," a former Tesla senior engineer told CNN in an interview.

But the EV and robot markets are very different, the engineer said.

"With electric vehicles, Tesla was really the only one working on this hard problem. There's a lot of companies now and tons of competition."

Musk laid out a literal replacement of Tesla cars by robots. (Supplied)

'Infinite money glitch'

Tesla first unveiled its humanoid robot project at a 2021 event, where a silvery figure danced to thumping techno music on a stage.

It was an actor in a robot suit, complete with a face that looked like a screen. "Obviously, that's not real," Musk said as the costumed figure left the stage.

Just months later, in January 2022, Musk said he thought Optimus could be "more significant than the vehicle business" for Tesla over time.

Tesla says Optimus can now sort objects, serve popcorn, throw out trash and dance.

It does "some basic tasks in the factory," Musk said Wednesday, progress, but still a far cry from Musk's futuristic vision, even as he predicted Optimus could eventually generate $US10 trillion ($14 trillion) of revenue.

Yet Musk has set a speedy timeline for Optimus.

At the World Economic Forum this month, he said the robot will be available for sale by the end of 2027.

It is a lofty goal, one experts say may be tougher than Musk's bets on electric vehicles or SpaceX.

READ MORE: Melbourne nail salon firebombed twice in two days

Musk has set a speedy timeline for Optimus. (AP)

Humanoid robots are among the most complex machines imaginable, and the race to build them is already heating up.

Tesla is not the only company in this space.

Hyundai and Google DeepMind are also deploying their Atlas humanoid robot internally in the coming months before rolling it out to customers.

Meanwhile, the CES tech show in January was full of companies, including Nvidia, Qualcomm and Intel, showing off humanoid robots powered by their chips and technologies.

More than 90 companies have a humanoid robot product, according to Ani Kelkar, a partner at McKinsey & Company who leads the firm's advanced automation and autonomy sector. More are coming, especially in the United States and China.

Experts from McKinsey, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley estimate the humanoid robot market could eventually be worth anywhere from $US370 billion ($524 billion) by 2040 to $US5 trillion ($7 trillion) by 2050.

Tesla does have critical advantages in its expertise in motors, batteries and mechanisms, said Ken Goldberg, a professor who supervises research in robotics and automation at the University of California, Berkeley.

"They also understand how to make something advanced in high volume – with cost effectiveness, and that's really important," Goldberg said.

READ MORE: Man kept alive for 48 hours with lungs removed

Musk's commentary and support of US President Donald Trump have made him a polarising figure. (AP)

The company could also benefit from using Optimus internally and selling it externally, giving it a "cost advantage" that could enable Tesla to make "several thousand dollars per robot," Goldman Sachs said in an October report.

But most experts agree it'll be at least a decade before humanoid robots are widely deployed.

"A giant leap may happen, but we don't know when," Goldberg said.

"Most technology develops as a slow burn over time, so I think the expectations about having fully general humanoids seems over-inflated."

Others are sceptical about whether humanoid robots will ever be broadly useful in society.

Bill Ray, an analyst following emerging technologies and robotics for market research firm Gartner, previously told CNN that humanoid robots face too many limitations to be practical.

Optimus challenges

Musk has swung big with timelines before – and missed. He previously said Tesla cars would be fully autonomous by 2018, and that SpaceX would start sending rockets to Mars by 2018 – neither of which has happened yet.

And already with Optimus, Tesla has missed its leader's ambitious schedule. Musk had initially set internal goals for Tesla to produce at least 5000 Optimus units in 2025, according to The Information .

That goal was slashed to 2000 a few months later and has been lowered again since, The Information reported in October.

Tesla did not respond to CNN's request for comment.

Musk has acknowledged that his goals are not easy.

"Right now, we're struggling with the final design of the hardware," especially of the arm and hand, Musk said at the All In Summit in September.

"Human-like hands are notoriously hard for robots to emulate. Unlike people, robots have a hard time knowing how to grip different objects like a wet glass versus a piece of metal.

"People think of space travel as extraordinarily difficult, and it is, no doubt, but it turns out that getting a robot to reliably tie a sneaker is harder than getting a rocket out of the atmosphere," Goldberg said.

Musk's political commentary and support of US President Donald Trump have also made him a polarising figure, resulting in protests and vandalism at Tesla dealerships across the country.

Protests and vandalism occured at Tesla dealerships across the country. (Getty)

A man uses chalk to write messages on the side of a San Francisco Tesla store during a protest. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

"If they won't buy his cars, why would they buy a huge robot for their home from him?" posted Ross Gerber, an early Tesla investor and CEO of investment firm Gerber Kawasaki, who is now a prominent critic of Musk.

Musk acknowledged the "many who doubt our ambitions for creating amazing abundance" on Wednesday's earnings call.

"But we're confident it can be done, and that we're making the right moves technologically to ensure that it does."

"And Tesla's obviously never been a company to shy away from solving some of the hardest problems," he added.

But Musk's version of the future won't happen instantly – and maybe not for a long time.

"Elon is a visionary, but he promises things that sometimes may take more time than his engineers can deliver," said Goldberg.

"The research community all over the world is working very hard on this, but it's not going to get solved overnight."

title: 'Cold shower' for mortgage holders: Experts' gloomy rates' forecast
text:
M﻿ortgage holders across Australia are likely to be hit with an interest rate hike next week, according to a survey of experts.

More than half the 33 economists and financial experts in the Finder Cash Rate Survey believe a sudden spike in inflation will force the Reserve Bank of Australia's hand when it announces its decision next Tuesday.

New inflation data released this week showed the trimmed mean, the RBA's preferred measure of ﻿underlying inflation , increased to 3.3 per cent and headline inflation shot up to 3.8 per cent in the year to December – both well outside the central bank's target band.

Mortgage holders are likely to be hit with an interest rate hike next week, experts forecast. (Photo by ROB HOMER SPECIAL 103506) (Rob Homer) (Nine)

The Finder research found 17 of those surveyed, or 51 per cent, believe the central bank will green-light a 0.25 per cent rise in the cash rate, raising it to 3.85 per cent﻿.

This is a marked turnaround from last December when only 9 per cent of experts in a Finder survey forecast a February rates lift.

Head of Finder consumer research Graham Cooke says the big four banks and most economists are now backing a hike.

"This news will feel like a cold shower for homeowners after a brief reprieve.

"Many who refinanced or entered the market during the 2025 easing cycle may feel blindsided, as the pivot from falling to rising rates in just six months has created significant whiplash."

READ MORE: ﻿ How Australian spy base could play role in US strike on Iran

Adding to the gloomy outlook, more than four in five experts who weighed in believe a rate cut in the next 12 months is unlikely.﻿

Homeowners on the average home loan of $693,802 will see an annual increase of $1313 to their mortgage repayments if the RBA raises the cash rate by 0.25 per cent next Tuesday.

On a $1 million mortgage, the same hike would cost a homeowner nearly $1893 a year more in interest – a rise of $158.

A rates rise next week would be the first in Australia since November 2023, and would follow the RBA's easing cycle that brought relief for mortgage holders. ﻿

Cooke says mortgage they should now scrutinise their interest rate with the easing cycle unlikely to restart again soon.﻿

"If your rate isn't one of the best, now might be a good time to give yourself a rate cut. Many banks will also throw in some cash for your trouble."

NEVER MISS A STORY: Get your breaking news and exclusive stories first by following us across all platforms.

Before acting on any information on this website you should consider the appropriateness of the information having regard to your objectives, financial situation and needs.

title: 'Exclusively only for you': Deposit scam targets desperate renters
text:
Scammers are preying on desperate Perth renters struggling to get a roof over their heads.

Fake "private landlords" on Facebook Marketplace are promising listings below market price for a costly deposit.

They're posting real pictures of real properties to lure their victims, but the prices are often too good to be true.

READ MORE: Kids shelter on bus as cops open fire outside school

They're posting real pictures of real properties to lure their victims but the prices are often too good to be true. (9News)

Finding a rental has never been this hard and WA Commissioner for Consumer Protection Trish Blake says it's a "perfect playground for scammers".

"[There's ]a lot of grooming by these scammers," she said.

"So they'll tell you that they're there to help the underdog and that you're the perfect person, they can see that you're a real battler, that you're a good person and they want to help you out."

Messages show how the scammers take advantage of the high demand for rentals.

"Due to the large number of people making offers for the apartment and which I can not attend to all.. my lawyer mandated a commitment fee to secure the apartment and filter out many people to secure it down for one person," one message reads.

"You can have the space secured ahead of your move in date by paying a security deposit of the first week rent of $400.

Scammers are preying on desperate Perth renters struggling to get a roof over their heads. (9News)

"The deposit act more like a commitment fee which is fully refundable if upon physical visit you have a change of mind and it will be added to your first week rent if everything goes as planned.

"The deposit secure down the apartment for you and it will be reserved exclusively only for you.. I will stop taking offers for it and remove it from the Market.﻿"

Blake warned renters not to hand over any money before they'd seen the property.

In 2025, at least 20 people reported a rental scam, losing $50,000, an increase of 27 per cent compared to the year before.

Median rental prices in Perth are at record highs.

READ MORE: Aussie astronomers discover potentially habitable planet

Fake "private landlords" on Facebook marketplace promising listings below market price for a costly deposit. (9News)

It costs $700 per week for a house and $670 to rent a unit while properties are snatched up in just 16 days.

"People have pure desperation and people will do what they can for their family and think they're doing the right thing and potentially dealing with unsavoury characters," Real Estate Institute of Western Australia member Rob Mandanici said.

title: Scarlett had a shortness of breath. Years later, she was put on life support
text:
Scarlett Hack was just 10 years old when she started experiencing a shortness of breath and heart palpitations.

Her symptoms were dismissed as anxiety, which she suffered with at the time, but her parents persisted and took her to several doctors before she was given an echocardiogram.

She was diagnosed with ﻿hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, a genetic heart condition where the muscle thickens.

READ MORE: ﻿ Australian astronomers discover potentially habitable planet

Scarlett Hack was diagnosed with two heart diseases. (Supplied)

"The heart disease was spontaneous in me. My entire family doesn't have any record of it, only me," she told 9news.com.au. ﻿

"After the doctor's appointment, my parents were told by the doctor, 'You should learn CPR as this has no cure'."

Hack's symptoms only worsened over the next three years until she was diagnosed with a second heart disease called ﻿arrhythmia burden disease - the time the heart spends in abnormal rhythm.

She fainted often, which caused her heart to stop each time, and eventually had an internal defibrillator installed.

During a doctor's appointment, ﻿her heart started racing and she went into cardiac arrest.

"I was screaming to my dad, 'Don't let me die, don't let me die'," she said.

﻿"It was very traumatising."

Scarlett was put onto life support. (Supplied)

Hack was in cardiac arrest for 40 minutes and then put on life support.

Her parents had two choices: let her go or wait for a heart donor.

"I only had two weeks to get it. If not, I'd be declared brain dead," she said.

"On the eighth day, my parents got the call at 2am, and they had a heart for me, and then I went into surgery at 7am."

Now aged 18, Hack ﻿is studying nursing so she can care for other children who may be in the same position she was in.

New data by the Heart Research Institute found 144,000 Australians are living with a deadly heart disease, which claims nine lives and causes 170 hospitalisations each day.

Of those who survive heart failure, 65 per cent return to the emergency department within a year. ﻿

READ MORE: ﻿ Three things could save Aussies from looming interest rate hell

Now 18, Scarlett is studying nursing. (Supplied)

Heart Research Institute ﻿chief executive Andrew Coats said many people were unaware their heart was failing to pump blood and oxygen around the body as it should.

"Heart disease can affect any one of us," he said.

"For too many Australians, it strikes without warning, taking the lives of loved ones far too soon."

Part of the issue is awareness.

Hack urged anyone with symptoms of heart disease to get themselves checked. ﻿

"There's no harm in you getting checked out by a doctor﻿," she said.

title: 'Carnage' at Perth greyhound track prompts calls to end racing
text:
Calls to end greyhound racing have intensified after a night of "carnage" at a Perth suburban race track that saw four dogs injured and two euthanased.

Races at the Cannington greyhound track were abandoned on Wednesday night after race seven of a scheduled 12, after the four dogs were injured, according to Racing and Wagering WA (RWWA).

Canning Mayor Patrick Hall has urged the state government to "read the room" and set a date for transitioning the state away from greyhound racing.

'Most deadly' greyhound track

"On Wednesday this week, absolute carnage out there, on a fine night, on a dry track," Cr Hall told ABC Radio Perth.

"I have no pride in the fact that the most deadly track, greyhound track, in the whole of Australia is located right here in the City of Canning.

"I think you have to draw a line in the sand sometimes and step up to the plate, and meet the expectations of your own community."

Patrick Hall has described Wednesday's greyhound racing meet as "carnage". (ABC News: Gian De Poloni)

RWWA declined an interview but in a statement said track-side veterinarians and racing stewards "acted to ensure all injured greyhounds received appropriate care and attention" after the incidents.

"Racing WA officials are currently conducting a comprehensive review of these incidents and assessing all available data prior to the continuation of any further racing or trialling at Cannington," the spokesperson said.

"Racing WA extends its sympathies to the connections involved and will continue to ensure the care, safety and welfare of all racing animals remains a priority."

The Cannington track was closed temporarily in 2024 for maintenance and a safety upgrade, which reportedly cost RWWA $3 million.

Inquiry underway

There were 119 greyhound deaths on tracks in Australia last year, according to data collated by the Coalition for the Protection of Greyhounds.

The most deadly tracks, according to the Coalition, were the Cannington and Mandurah racetracks in WA, with 10 deaths recorded at each track.

A parliamentary inquiry is underway, which was prompted by a petition with more than 26,000 signatures calling for the industry to be phased out.

Two dogs were euthanased follling Wednesday's event in Cannignotn. (Facebook: Greyhounds WA)

Mel Harrison, president of advocacy group Free The Hounds, said Australia had more greyhound racetracks than there were across the globe combined, and has long called for greyhound racing to be stopped.

"I'd love to say it's the first time anything like this has happened, but sadly, it's not," she told ABC Radio Perth.

Ms Harrison said it was disingenuous for the industry and its supporters to say they cared for the welfare of the greyhounds.

"That's fine if you're prepared to accept that dogs die for this … but then stop hiding behind all the welfare speech, and saying that you care so much about the dogs," she said.

She said there needed to be more transparency and independent oversight of the industry.

The RWWA spokesperson said "the welfare of all racing animals is Racing WA's highest priority".

title: Nine Radio sold for cut-price $56m to pub tycoon Arthur Laundy
text:
Nine Entertainment has taken a loss by selling its radio network to billionaire pub baron Arthur Laundy as the media company takes a big punt on outdoor advertising.

Mr Laundy's Laundy Family Office will pay $56 million for the network, which includes Melbourne's top-rating talk station 3AW, Sydney's 2GB and a stable of presenters, including Ben Fordham and Tom Elliott.

Mr Laundy has an estimated net worth of $1.75 billion and owns more than 40 pubs in NSW.

He is the father of former Liberal MP Craig Laundy, who was a junior minister in Malcolm Turnbull's government, and Stu Laundy, a former contestant on Network 10's dating show The Bachelorette.

The sale price is far less than the $275m the network was worth just seven years ago when Nine took full control of what was then known as Macquarie Media.

Arthur Laundy (left) appeared on Clinton Maynard's 2GB show in August 2025. (Supplied: 2GB)

At the time, Macquarie's Sydney stars included Alan Jones — currently before the courts charged with multiple counts of indecent assault — and Ray Hadley, who retired last year.

Nine's culture of bullying and sexual harassment revealed Bosses in Nine's broadcast division would belittle, intimidate, gaslight and sexually harass employees, and when complaints were made against management, HR would cover it up.

Long-time 3AW breakfast host Neil Mitchell, who dominated the ratings in Melbourne, also retired in 2023.

The exit of stars added extra pressure on top of the continued decline of the entire talk radio industry as digital media grabbed younger audiences and left broadcasters competing for a shrinking band of baby boomer listeners.

At the same time as selling the radio stations, Nine on Friday splashed $850m buying outdoor ad company QMS from private equity group Quadrant.

It also sold its regional TV station, NBN, to affiliate WIN, which already rebroadcasts Nine throughout much of Australia, for $14.8m.

Nine has lost faith in the future of radio, analysts say. (ABC News)

Nine chief executive Matt Stanton told the stock exchange the shake-up would "create a more efficient, higher-growth, and digitally powered Nine Group for our consumers, advertisers, shareholders and people".

Veteran media analyst Peter Cox said this contradicted the positive narrative about radio put out by Nine's competitor, the newly merged Seven West Media and Southern Cross Austereo.

"Southern Cross and Seven are saying radio is the future," he told the ABC.

"But here's Nine saying that 'No, we don't think that's the future, it's billboards by the side of the road'.

" I'm a great believer that traditional media is dying; I've been saying that for many years in many ways. "

Nine is expected to reap about $50m in cash from the sale after transaction costs and debt adjustments are made.

CEO Matt Stanton says he hopes the shake-up will make Nine's business model "more efficient". (Supplied)

This will be booked as a gain of about $10m because last year the company dramatically wrote down the value of the network in its accounts.

Nine the latest casualty from slowing economy In announcing 200 job losses on Friday, Nine Entertainment has joined other commercial media outlets in feeling the chill from a cooling economy as more corporate budgets slash their marketing spend.

It also stands to book a tax benefit of about $50m because for tax purposes it is making a loss compared to the original purchase price.

The sale of the radio network will be greeted with relief by many inside Nine's publishing division, which runs metro mastheads The Age and The Sydney Morning Herald as well as The Australian Financial Review.

Some within the relatively buttoned-up newspaper division have been unhappy to be sharing ownership with the more rambunctious right-wingers at the radio network.

However, Nine told the ASX it would continue to collaborate with the radio stations under the Laundy group's ownership.

"Laundy is expected to remain a long-term partner of Nine, with plans to utilise Nine News journalists on radio, showcase Stan Sport through Laundy venues, provide promotion and advertising sales collaboration, as well as increased advertising spend by Laundy on Nine properties," the company said.

title: Australia taking Nipah virus seriously but no changes to border control
text:
The federal health minister says there are no immediate plans to tighten border controls after cases of a deadly virus were detected in India.

Nipah virus has been detected in two people in West Bengal and countries across Asia are stepping up health screening measures, including at airports.

The virus is most commonly spread by fruit bats and although infections in people are rare, the World Health Organisation said it can have a 40 to 75 per cent fatality rate in humans.

Health Minister Mark Butler told ABC's Radio National the federal government was taking the situation seriously but was not considering additional border measures.

"We don't have any advice at the moment to change our existing protocols for sick travellers who arrive in Australia. There already are protocols for that, but we'll continue to watch the situation closely," Mr Butler said.

"There's reason to hope that this has been contained."

Airport health authorities are monitoring passengers from international flights arriving in Bangkok, Thailand. (Suvarnabhumi Airport Office /Handout via Reuters)

'We shouldn't panic': expert

The virus, which has never been detected in Australia, is a zoonotic disease like COVID-19 and Ebola, meaning it's spread from animals to humans, but there are major differences to COVID-19 in how it spreads, as it is not transmissible through airborne droplets.

"It's very difficult to transmit between humans," Mr Butler said.

"It requires very close personal contact between humans and the exchange effectively of bodily fluids."

Sanjaya Senanayake, associate professor of medicine at the Australian National University, said there was "no reason to panic" .

"It is not a brand new virus. It's been around since 1999 … and we see annual outbreaks of Nipah virus in countries like Bangladesh every year," Dr Senanayake said.

"It's something we've known about for a long time and we have outbreaks every year in that region of Asia and we haven't panicked before, so we shouldn't panic now."

Two Nipah cases had been detected at the Narayana Multispeciality Hospital in the eastern Indian state of West Bengal, since December. (AP Photo)

The Australian Centre for Disease Control said it is uncommon for the virus to spread between people, as prolonged close contact with an infected person is required for transmission, such as when a healthcare worker is caring for an infected patient.

There is no vaccine for Nipah virus but the World Health Organisation says several candidate vaccines are currently in different stages of development.

Vaccine development has faced challenges because outbreak sizes are generally small which makes vaccine efficacy trials difficult to conduct.

Dr Sanjaya Senanayake says it's not a brand new virus and is difficult to transmit. (Supplied)

Dr Senanayake said only about 750 cases of Nipah virus have been recorded in almost 30 years.

"I suspect if we ever got to a stage where there were concerns about pandemics like COVID, the research and production could be ramped up," he said.

"We don't have any antivirals against it. So if someone does get Nipah, it's what we call supportive care, just general measures."

More screening at some Asian borders

Several Asian countries such as Thailand, Indonesia, Vietnam and Pakistan have ramped up health screening at their borders in recent days with some airports using thermal screening or body temperature scanners to check travellers, particularly those arriving from India.

The precautions come as the region prepares for a travel surge over the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday season which begins in about a fortnight.

Asian countries taking no chances with deadly virus Two cases of the Nipah virus have been detected in India, prompting a raft of screening measures to be enacted in countries across Asia.

However, India's health ministry said there was no plan to screen passengers at Indian airports as the situation did not justify it.

"There is no outbreak. There were just two cases in one district in [West] Bengal and there is no spread," an official told Reuters.

The ministry said it had traced 196 close contacts of the two positive cases and all had tested negative for the virus.

The two infected people are nurses at the same hospital and one is likely to be discharged from hospital soon while the other remains in a critical condition.

Nipah virus can cause flu-like symptoms such as fever, headache, fatigue, vomiting and shortness of breath four days to three weeks after infection.

In some cases, people develop pneumonia or encephalitis (inflammation of the brain), but most people who survive make a full recovery.

title: Live: Gadecki and Peers in mixed doubles final before Alcaraz, Zverev kick off men's semis
text:
As with the format of the mixed doubles, we are now off to a 10-point match tie-break to decide the Australian Open title.

The French win the first point on serve. 1-0 Mladenovic/Guinard.

A solid Peers second serve draws the error from Guinard. 1-1

Peers second serve ends with Mladenovic splitting the Aussie pair with a drive down the middle of the court. Mini-break for 2-1 Mladenovic/Guinard.

Nerves from Mladenovic, who double faults, hitting her partner on the head on second serve. 2-2

Another second serve, and Gadecki ends the rally with a whipped crosscourt backhand. Aussies now a mini-break ahead! 3-2 Gadecki/Peers

Brilliant deep return from Guinard and Gadecki nets. Back on serve at 3-3

Everyone has nerves here, as they should — there is a grand slam title on the line.

Second serve for Gadecki. And it's a double fault! 4-3 Mladenovic/Guinard

Ten points seems a long way away at this point.

Guinard holds and the French lead 5-3.

Second serve, and a brilliant net exchange from Peers sets up the error from Guinard. Back on serve again! 5-4 Mladenovic/Guinard.

Now a second serve from Peers is drilled by Guinard and Gadecki nets. 6-4 Mladenovic/Guinard

Another second serve, and Peers comes forward to drill the winner off a kick serve. 6-5 Mladenovic/Guinard

Two vital serves from Mladenovic, and she gets the first point! 7-5 Mladenovic/Guinard

The French are three points away.

Great rally, with Mladenovic and Gadecki exchanging moonballs, but Gadecki's crosscourt draws the net shot from Guinard. Back on serve at 7-6 Mladenovic/Guinard

A tense return from Guinard to Gadecki goes low on the net. 7-7

Almost an ace from Gadecki! The crowd goes up then sighs. But Mladenovic drills a forehand well over the baseline. 8-7 Gadecki/Peers

And a hammerblow of a forehand from Peers gives two championship points! 9-7 Gadecki/Peers

French hold for 8-9. Still championship point!

Second serve from Peers.

title: Why Lachie Neale is having his 'best pre-season in a long time' despite drama
text:
Brisbane coach Chris Fagan says Lachie Neale is enjoying his best pre-season in years despite the Lions champion dealing with significant personal issues.

The dual Brownlow medallist relinquished the co-captaincy earlier in January amid a tumultuous and public marriage breakdown.

Neale, one of the greatest players in club history after moving from Fremantle at the end of 2018, will likely return to Western Australia in 2027 to be closer to his two children.

Lachie Neale steps down as Brisbane Lions co-captain The club said the 32-year-old had made the decision following a "challenging personal period".

But until then, the 32-year-old will remain a crucial part of Brisbane's push to claim a third consecutive premiership this season.

"It hasn't really affected things too much," Fagan told SEN on Friday when asked about the intense tabloid interest in Neale's personal life.

"It's not like we sit around having meetings with the players and talk about it.

"It's just been myself, [Lions football boss] Danny [Daly] and Lachie.

"To Lachie's credit, in terms of the way that he's training and going about things, he's having his best pre-season in a long while.

"Normally, he's finished seasons quite injured and been in rehab, but this year he had no injury at the finish.

"He's been able to train fully and in the best shape he's been in for ages in terms of setting himself up for a good football season.

"He's in a good place at the moment, obviously got a bit going on personally, but he seems to be coping with that pretty well."

In three seasons as co-captain with Harris Andrews, Neale led the Lions to three grand finals — winning the last two.

Coming towards the end of his career, Neale had already raised the prospect of stepping back as a leader before his marriage breakdown turned into a social media storm.

Neale gave up the Lions co-captaincy after a high profile marriage breakdown. (AAP: Jono Searle)

Talks took place last year about Andrews being the Lions' sole captain.

But due to the success the Lions have had with co-captains — Dayne Zorko was skipper for five seasons before 2023 — Fagan is superstitious about changing that.

A player vote will take place in February that will help shape Brisbane's captaincy system for 2026.

"Harris Andrews could easily be captain on his own," Fagan said.

"I am not a fan of the two-captain model but since we have had it, we have been successful.

"I don't know if I want one or two.

"If it's two, then you look at Hugh McCluggage and Josh Dunkley and it's hard to split those two blokes."

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

The Lions have taken a similar approach to when they broke through to win the 2024 premiership in a bid to stay at the top — humility in success.

"Straight away after the grand final, we talked about it — we can only be our own worst enemies if we get too carried away with ourselves and we don't stay humble," Fagan said.

"It's a regular topic of conversation.

"The boys know what that behaviour looks like, and we encourage them to call it out if they see it.

"We certainly do if we do.

"But to be fair, I haven't seen any of that to this point in time.

"We turned up in great shape and attitude at training has been terrific."

The Lions will unfurl their premiership flag when they host the Western Bulldogs at the Gabba in opening round on March 7.

AAP

title: Para-athletes 'devastated by sudden, unexplained decision' to withdraw team
text:
Australia's top wheelchair basketball team was "devastated" to learn it had been withdrawn from this season's national competition, sparking calls to "urgently" reverse the shock decision.

In a joint statement released on Thursday, Darwin Salties co-captains Tom O'Neill-Thorne and CJ McCarthy-Grogan revealed players only heard about the decision — made overnight on Wednesday — through media the following morning.

They said Basketball NT (BNT) provided players with "no reason" for pulling out of the National Wheelchair Basketball League (NWBL) 2026 season and said there had been "no prior consultation with the team".

Tom O'Neill-Thorne and CJ McCarthy-Grogan co-captained the Darwin team to three consecutive National Wheelchair Basketball League championships. (Supplied)

O'Neill-Thorne said players had been "totally blindsided" and "devastated by the sudden and unexplained decision" from BNT.

"It's shattering for the team but, more than us, it's distressing that the next generation of wheelchair basketball players might not get the same opportunities we all got playing for the Salties," he said.

"We're still trying to get some answers on what's happened but we are appealing directly to Basketball NT to reverse the decision."

The Darwin Salties joined the national men's wheelchair basketball competition in 2022, taking home the past three consecutive championships including last year's grand final in Sydney, and players have gone on to represent Australia at the 2023 World Championships and 2024 Paris Paralympics.

"The Salties have helped put the NT on the national and international wheelchair basketball map," McCarthy-Grogan said.

" That should be supported, not shut out. "

Why was the team withdrawn?

McCarthy-Grogan urged BNT to "provide transparency" around how the decision was made, and said the team "finding out through a media statement is incredibly disappointing".

He worried about the potential flow-on impacts to "disability representation, opportunity and pathways in the Northern Territory".

Speaking with ABC Radio Darwin this week, McCarthy-Grogan said the decision was particularly upsetting in the lead-up to Australia hosting the 2032 Olympic and Paralympic Games.

"We'd made so much progress over the years and, in the lead-up to the 2032 Games in Brisbane and Gold Coast, you would expect that they would have been supportive but unfortunately, it's not the case," he said.

In a statement, BNT said it "acknowledges and shares the disappointment felt by the basketball community" in response to the decision.

The Darwin Salties first heard about the withdrawal decision in a media release. (Supplied)

It said Darwin Basketball Association (DBA) previously held the NWBL licence and operated the Top End wheelchair basketball program, but when DBA "entered administration in December 2025" BNT was asked if "it would assume responsibility for fielding a new Darwin team for the 2026 season".

The BNT board decided it couldn't "take on the financial and operational risks of entering a national league team without committed ongoing funding", which it described as a "prudent but difficult decision".

"As a result of DBA ceasing operations, BNT is focused on commencing a new Darwin local competition, rebuilding governance confidence and long-term financial sustainability of basketball across the territory," the statement said.

'A line in the sand'

On Thursday afternoon, WBA executive general manager John Palmer told ABC Radio Darwin the national body had been "confident" Basketball NT could "move forward" until "very recently".

"We've extended our deadline compared to other teams — over six weeks longer than any other team — and unfortunately, NT Basketball couldn't meet those deadlines as of this morning when we were notified, after a board meeting last night, that NT Basketball had decided not to move forward with the licence, so disappointing all around," he said.

"It's a difficult decision.

"From the financial prudence point of view, I suppose we needed to say; 'Look, there's a line in the sand', we needed an answer and that's where we're at."

How two NT friends helped form the Darwin Salties Tom and CJ have been friends for decades. Now the two mates, who had to leave home for their sporting opportunities, have reunited to bring those opportunities home.

In a statement to the ABC on Friday, Mr Palmer said "the Darwin Salties depart the league at the very top of the sport".

"While the Salties will not take the court in 2026, the league remains committed to supporting the growth of para-sport in the region," he said.

He thanked the team for being "a benchmark for excellence", fans of the sport, and the staff and volunteers who worked to keep the league running.

"Their dominance on the court was matched only by the fervour of the Darwin fans who turned the stadium into a fortress," Mr Palmer said.

title: What's lamb's fry, and why is it popular at this canteen
text:
Every Wednesday morning at the Mount Gambier saleyards, Liz Beames gets in at 4am to start cooking up lamb's fry.

She runs the canteen on site, and while it might not be everyone's cup of tea, her lamb's fry for breakfast is popular.

The traditional dish, which usually includes lamb liver and is thus rich in iron, was once a popular menu item at pubs, kitchens and clubs around Australia, but has since largely disappeared from many venues.

But not at the canteen at Mount Gambier and District Saleyards, where the tradition isn't just going strong, it's their speciality.

Lamb's fry is one of Mount Gambier Saleyards' signature dishes. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

"I used to make it just in the winter periods and then some of the older fellas said to me, 'Can't you do this all year round?'" she said.

"They love it. I don't mind making it, but I have never tasted it."

It is this kind of dedication that has Mount Gambier and District Saleyards in the running for Saleyards Australia's Best Canteen competition, which is encouraging people to vote for their favourite site.

Saleyards Australia executive officer Amy Perfrement said every saleyard had its own characters, but the canteens were often the heart and soul of livestock exchanges.

Workers put a lot of effort into Australian Saleyards' canteens. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

"One part of saleyards that's often forgotten about is the canteen ... we wanted to just shine a bit of a spotlight on those unsung heroes that keep everyone fed and watered on sale day and sometimes the days either side of that," she said.

There are just under 80 canteens across the country that are registered as Saleyards Australia members, and many more unregistered operators.

Often run by small businesses, volunteers, or community groups, Ms Perfrement said the canteens helped foster connection, goodwill and a welcoming atmosphere.

Alongside the vanilla slices, bacon and egg sandwiches and fresh coffee, the canteens are often a meeting place for rural communities.

Liz Beames grew up on a farm and says her background helps her to connect with the community. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

"It's a place where people can come in and meet, have a chat, maybe a debrief, and it really is that social fabric of saleyards," Ms Perfrement said.

More than just a canteen

When Liz Beames first started at the Mount Gambier saleyards as the canteen manager, she thought she might stay for maybe three months.

In May, she will have been in the role for 18 years.

Over those years of serving the saleyard community, she counts many of them as family.

The business has been a family affair for Liz Beames, who has worked alongside her husband and children over the years. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

"I love them all, they're great. They're salt of the earth people, and I love what I do, and I want that to come through in my food," Ms Beames said.

And like family, Ms Beames knows exactly what each regular wants to order.

"There is a few that have been here for a long time and I know that they will have the bacon, eggs, bit of toast — always the same," she said.

Breakfast is popular at the Mount Gambier and District Saleyards. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

Meantime, Megan Ireland — who runs the Naracoorte saleyard canteen, which is also in the running — agrees that homemade meals cooked with love were always a winner.

"I make everything from scratch, from my homemade jelly slice to a fresh soup in winter or a salad in summer," she said.

"I like to support local business as well, so local eggs, the local butcher, the bakery."

A hot meal and a welcoming smile are what make saleyard canteens a farmer favourite. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

She also agrees that some of the best customers are the ones who are not even there to take part in the sale.

"Some of the older blokes come in every Tuesday or every Friday just so they can feel like they're a part of it," Ms Ireland said.

"They're some of our favourite customers. Every single sale day they sit at the same table, they order the same thing, and they give you the same smile."

A community hub

David Wallis is the saleyards manager in Mount Gambier and knows all too well the importance of a good saleyard canteen.

David Wallis says canteen workers deserve recognition. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

"This is a hub where people feel like they're involved. Farmers are often isolated in what they do, and so to come to the saleyards, and in particular the canteen, they feel like they have someone that is happy to have a chat," he said.

" It's more than just a feed in the canteen, it's about wellbeing as well. "

Saleyard canteens around the country keep sellers, buyers and agents well fed on busy days. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

Mr Wallis said canteens could act as a barometer of how the community was feeling.

"[Liz Beames] will come to me and say, 'Oh, the vibe today is amazing', or there might be other days where it might be a really elongated day, and people are tired," he said.

"But she also is just an ear for many."

And the saleyard canteen is never missed by Mr Wallis either.

"I have been here nearly six years and I have eaten every sale day here," he said.

"[Ms Beames] has this bad habit of bringing in a little bowl of lollies to people when they have worked real long hours.

Saleyards Australia wants to find the best saleyards canteen in the country. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

"You have just about had enough for the day, and Liz will come in with a smile and say, 'Just to keep you going', and walk out again.

"It's those little things that make a lot of difference."

Voting for Australia's Best Saleyards Canteen closes at 11pm on Saturday, January 31, with the winner announced in February.

title: It has been backed by Trump and Rinehart — but where is the Arafura mine?
text:
It is the Central Australian mine promised to help upset China's dominance of the global rare earths market, and bring hundreds of jobs to the Northern Territory.

Arafura's Nolans Rare Earths Project was listed as a priority in a multi-billion dollar critical minerals deal inked between Donald Trump and Anthony Albanese in Washington last year.

The Nolans Project has also received backing from Australia's richest woman, Gina Rinehart.

Accommodation for workers has been established at the project site, but the Arafura Rare Earths mine is yet to materialise. (Supplied: Arafura Rare Earths)

But 20 years after it was first floated as a prospect, and after receiving hundreds of millions of dollars in taxpayer funding, the project appears to be delayed once again.

Arafura Rare Earths released its quarterly report on Thursday, which showed the company was still vague on exactly when it might hit its golden milestone of final investment.

Late last year, following the deal with the United States, the company's heads told media they were hopeful of reaching a final investment decision by the first quarter of 2026.

Gina Rinehart's company Hancock owns a 10 per cent stake in Arafura Rare Earths. (AAP: Richard Wainwright)

In this week's quarterly report, the firm said it was now awaiting confirmation of further investment from the German government, and has pushed its timeline out.

Arafura had previously said a final investment decision had been expected early in 2025.

Shareholder nerves over delays

Arafura has not committed to an exact timeline for a start date, but said in a statement to the ABC there was still a decision "targeted for the first half of the calendar 2026".

Why this multi-million-dollar project is powering ahead As the major parties make their final pitches ahead of the NT election, both say they have the answers to turn around the territory's stagnant economy.

At an investor meeting yesterday, one shareholder asked: "How do you expect to reassure shareholders that this project will succeed due to constant delays?"

In response, Arafura managing director Darryl Cuzzubbo said, "90 per cent of that funding is committed, or subject to final approval.

"We are doing everything in our power to accelerate negotiations with cornerstone investors and efficiently navigate new and complex government equity programs, to deliver a fully-funded project, as soon as possible.

"The parties we are dealing with prioritise diligence and process, which serves to reinforce the project fundamentals that will deliver long-term value.

" By a similar token, we need to ensure that the solution that we put in place is on the best possible terms for our shareholders, and we are focusing on certainty over speed. "

Darryl Cuzzubbo assured stakeholders the majority of funding has already been secured. (AAP: Dominic Giannini)

Government accepts complexity of project

Arafura has also pledged the project, to be based north of Alice Springs, will bring hundreds of jobs to the territory.

In response to the latest quarterly report, NT Mining Minister Gerard Maley said the government looked forward to seeing progress from the company.

Gerard Maley is looking forward to seeing the project progress. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

"Projects of this scale and strategic importance involve complex and time-consuming financing processes," he said.

" [These are] ultimately commercial matters for Arafura, but we look forward to their progress. "

Australian Strategic Policy Institute senior fellow Ian Satchwell said the company's announcement it had not yet reached the final investment decision should be no surprise.

Ian Satchwell says he's confident the project will proceed. (ABC News: Glyn Jones)

"I think that everybody, including the principals at Arafura Rare Earths, would've liked this project to get a go ahead sooner than 2026," he said.

"But when you're dealing with a market that's quite volatile, where prices are being manipulated to hold out competition, and where you're trying to line up financial institutions with loans, plus equity investment … it's complicated.

" I'm very confident that this project, when it gets a final investment decision, will proceed, and hopefully will be very successful. "

Federal Resources Minister Madeleine King declined to comment.

title: Enthusiasts say goodbye to NSW 'steel rattler' train
text:
For many, the garish purple interiors of V-Set passenger train carriages bring back fond childhood memories of travelling from regional NSW to Sydney.

But after 55 years on the tracks, the beloved "steel rattlers" have reached the end of the line.

'Blue Goose' V-Set makes its final journey from Lithgow to Central Station in Sydney. (ABC News: Abubakr Sajid)

On Friday morning, the intercity workhorse rolled out of Lithgow for the last time painted in its original royal blue and grey 'Blue Goose' colours.

The 5:57am service stopped at most Blue Mountains Line stations before terminating at Sydney's Central Station, about 20 minutes later than expected due to demand.

Although the final service V-Set train has been painted in the original royal blue, the more recent fleet was known for its yellow front exterior. (ABC News: Liam Patrick)

First released in 1970, the V-Set trains continued to be manufactured for 19 years, with the more recent fleet known for its yellow front exterior.

Transport management lecturer Geoffrey Clinton from the University of Sydney puts its success down to the modern edge the series brought when it first hit the tracks.

"They had things like automatic [closing] doors and air conditioning, which was obviously quite an important thing, particularly in our hot summers and cold winters," Dr Clinton said.

Dr Clinton says the V-Set passenger train was ahead of its time. (Supplied: University of Sydney)

The V-Set's distinctive reversible seats also proved to be a drawcard, affording people a sense of autonomy in choosing who they sat with.

"There's a lot of people who formed friendships on those trains and that's because people would take the same carriage on the same train every day to and from work or school," Dr Clinton said.

"I know stories about people who would have Friday drinks on the train as a carriage and you play card games and whatnot."

Mr Thomas is a fan of the V-Set train. (Supplied: Paul Thomas)

Public transport enthusiast Paul Thomas travelled up to Lithgow to board the V-Set train's victory lap.

The social media vlogger embarked on the journey with hundreds of others early on Friday morning, with the belief its final trip would be a celebration as opposed to a sombre occasion.

"I was at Lithgow Station at five in the morning," he said.

"There were lots of people there, probably 300 or 400 rail fans, waiting for this train to come in."

'Blue Goose' V-Set train on its debut in October 1977 at Katoomba. (ABC News)

Mr Thomas said it was quite the party in the second car, but in his carriage the atmosphere was quite civilised.

Demand to board the Blue Goose's final run caused delays to the service, leaving eager commuters waiting on station platforms.

Thousands packed Sydney's Central Station this morning to say goodbye. (ABC News: Abubakr Sajid)

But for some passengers, the wait brought back the feeling of nostalgia rather than frustration.

"It brings back those childhood memories," said Katie Laws, who brought her family to Penrith Station to watch the model roll next to the platform for the final time.

"The trains being late helps too … bringing back those memories of waiting and getting on the train, running for the train."

The V-Set class has been replaced with the Mariyung Fleet. (ABC News: Anushri Sood)

The V-Set class will be succeeded by the Mariyung Fleet, which has already replaced trains on the Central Coast and Newcastle lines.

Despite passengers being unable to flip the seats on the newer model, train devotees welcome the trade-off for larger bathrooms and a quieter journey.

Aged just 10 years old, Zedd woke up at 5am to board the train with his dad.

He told the ABC he would miss travelling to the mountains on the Blue Goose, but was excited to be "part of history".

"This is one of the best trains on the inner-city network," he said.

"Also, this train is just nostalgic."

Zedd says he was excited to be "part of history". (ABC News.)

'An emotional moment'

Thousands eagerly packed Central Station to watch the train terminate for the final time.

As the last passengers of the V-Set disembarked, they were greeted to fanfare and a live band.

Transport Minister John Graham said it was an emotional day for not only Sydney's rail network, but generations of commuters.

"There's no question these V-Sets will be really missed as they retire today," he said.

"Incredible to have so many people down here... as we wave off for the final time these V-set trains."

Transport Minister John Graham and V-Set train driver Peter Gunczy. (ABC News: Abubakr Sajid)

Long-serving train driver, Peter Gunczy, said he was honoured to be given the opportunity to retire the fleet.

"I've spent the best part of 41 years driving these V-Sets," he said.

" It's really, really emotional for me personally. I'm trying really hard to not well up. "

Public to decide future of V-Set train carriages

The 'Blue Goose' V-Set used for the final service will be preserved for future train enthusiasts, with the fate of the other 81 retired carriages up to the public.

Dr Clinton expects most will be turned into scrap metal, but hopes to see some provided with a new life.

"In the past, we've seen them being repurposed as cafes and for accommodation," he said.

"Train carriages around the world have also been repurposed for things like artificial reefs, as they make a good artificial reef."

title: Kevin Muscat's Shanghai Port hit with points deduction following corruption investigation
text:
Kevin Muscat has managed Shanghai Port to two successive Chinese title triumphs but the Australian will face a huge hurdle if he goes for the "three-peat" after the champions were hit with a points deduction following an investigation into football corruption.

Shanghai, who won the Chinese Super League by just two points, must begin their defence of the title in March on minus five points after they were among nine top-flight clubs who were hit ⁠with substantial punishments announced by the Chinese FA on Thursday.

Shanghai Shenhua, who were runners-up to their neighbours, got an even tougher sanction of a 10-point deduction, along with Tianjin Jinmen Tiger, ‌who came sixth.

Muscat has enjoyed tremendous success as a manager throughout Asia. (Getty Images: Clicks Images)

The punishments ‍have been handed out by authorities after an investigation into football-related gambling and match manipulation, Chinese state news agency Xinhua reported.

The 52-year-old Muscat, who earned a reputation as one of the toughest, most uncompromising defenders in the British game, has since become hugely successful as a manager, with two titles in charge of Melbourne Victory and another with Yokohama F Marinos in Japan.

His exploits in China have since kept him on the radar of British clubs, and he had been in line to take over as manager of Scottish giants Rangers last October before the deal fell through.

Whether his attitude to life at his lucratively funded club will be changed by their punishment is not known, but only this week, Muscat's name has again come up in connection with the vacant manager's job at Championship side Leicester City, who sacked their boss Marti Cifuentes last week.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

Also, after the punishments in China, Qingdao Hainiu will start the season on minus seven ‌points while Henan FC and Shandong Taishan were both hit with six-point deductions.

Wuhan Three Towns, Zhejiang FC and Beijing ‍Guoan will start on minus five points alongside Port.

The teams have also been fined between 200,000 and 1 million yuan ($41,071 to $204,000).

The Chinese FA also said former CFA president Chen Xuyuan and ex-China coach Li Tie were among 73 people barred from football-related activities for life.

AAP

title: Are Australians ready for genetically modified tomatoes? The proof will be in the eating
text:
Genetically modified tomatoes the colour of a plum are set to go on sale in Australian fruit shops for the first time this year.

The Purple Bliss tomato has been approved by the Office of the Gene Technology Regulator and Food Standards Australia New Zealand, allowing it to be grown and distributed in Australia.

The purple tomato was bred to include genes from the snapdragon flower which adds colour and antioxidants.

It will be the first fresh GM whole food to be grown and sold in the country, with other GM crops in Australia only approved for cultivation.

Snapdragon fruit genes have been added to create the tomato's purple colour and increase health benefits. (Supplied: Norfolk Healthy Produce)

Victoria-based fresh produce marketing company All Aussie Farmers has been working for several years to bring the purple tomato to Australia from the United States.

Managing director Travis Murphy said the fruit had a "really sweet" flavour.

"I'm not a tomato eater, I can openly admit that, but I can eat these purple tomatoes. They're beautiful," he said.

Melbourne first to stock

Now that it is approved, All Aussie Farmers can begin growing and selling the Purple Bliss locally.

Travis Murphy says the purple tomato has a sweet flavour. (Supplied: Norfolk Healthy Produce)

They will be on sale in Melbourne fruit shops around the middle of the year before expanding to other markets.

"Because this is such a unique product, we want to control how it's introduced," Mr Murphy said.

"We'll be selling them ourselves off our own wholesale floor so we're handling everything end-to-end," he said.

"We can make sure the product is handled properly and that the grower is getting paid fairly."

That first grower is based in Queensland, in the Clearview Valley.

Travis Murphy (left) says it has been challenging to get regulatory approval for the purple tomato. (Supplied: All Aussie Farmers)

Mr Murphy said they were chosen because their main crop of medley tomatoes was wiped out by hail just before Christmas.

"He's a careful, committed grower who puts a lot of effort into his fruit," Mr Murphy said.

"That means we can deliver a top-quality product to fruit shops who can then pass that quality on to consumers."

A question for the consumer

Victorian Farmers Federation president Brett Hosking welcomed the go-ahead for the GM tomato, saying it was important technology was embraced.

Brett Hosking says science and farming work hand in hand. (Supplied: GrainGrowers)

"We're starting to realise that science and food production work hand in hand," he said.

"The way we ensure consumers get the best eating experience is by embracing what we know from research, innovation and technology combined with traditional growing practices.

"A lot of GM food products in Australia aren't actually consumed directly.

"Take canola, for example, we produce oil from it, [but] that oil doesn't contain any of the DNA.

"This tomato though is a product you put straight on your plate. A fresh food that you chop up and eat whole."

Second GM 'wave' unlikely

Unlike the purple tomato, most other GM crops in Australia are bred to solve pest, disease and agricultural issues.

But molecular plant biologist Joseph Pegler from the University of Newcastle doubts there would be a surge of GM crops modified for nutrition.

"It's certainly possible that we'll see more genetically modified crops in the future," Dr Pegler said.

"But this doesn't mean we're about to see a large influx of GM crops released into the Australian environment.

"The regulation around genetically modified organisms in Australia is very strict and highly transparent."

title: Australian Open 2026 LIVE updates: Aussies chase doubles title; Zverev battles Alcaraz, Djokovic faces Sinner in blockbuster semis
text:
I wonder if mixed doubles pairings have to take lessons in sign language and ventriloquism before signing up for the tour?

It sure looks that way in this Australian Open final.

Closed fists over mouths are just the ticket for the French pair. Credit: Getty Images

Mladenovic and Guinard have been spotted trying to communicate with their hands held over their mouths in a closed fist. It looks like they are trying to blow a pretend trumpet, but apparently they are talking tactics.

The Aussies are relying on hand signals to determine their approach to certain points.

Gadecki holds her left hand behind her back when she is standing at the net and goes through a number of different finger signals before her partner Peers serves.

In theory, it gives her the advantage of knowing where he is going to serve. If she signals wide to the forehand, she can cover the line. If she signals down the line, she can step across to cut off the volley.

title: Three Olympics, four surgeries and one superstition: ‘Moguls Matt’ takes bumpy road to Milan Games
text:
Save Log in , register or subscribe to save articles for later. Save articles for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them any time. Got it Normal text size Larger text size Very large text size In the tense moments before a high-pressure event, Winter Olympian Matt Graham looks for his daughter’s face. He pulls his phone from his pocket, lights up the screen and focuses on her image. It is a reassuring habit the 31-year-old moguls specialist has formed since becoming a father in September 2024 that will help drive him towards Winter Olympics gold next month. “I found myself doing it just this past season, which I didn’t expect,” he tells this masthead. Matt Graham with a world championships silver medal in 2023. Credit: Getty Images “She’s my background on my phone, so during competitions, when the stakes are high and the pressures up, I’d often just like, pull my phone out, just open it up, sort of blow her a kiss and just say, ‘let’s f...ing go’. “I just found myself doing that naturally. It wasn’t planned. It’s more my way of just getting in the zone and getting amped up for the event.”

Advertisement

Graham has embraced fatherhood. Despite the added complications for an athlete who lives in Sydney and competes on the other side of the globe, it provides him with extra motivation as he prepares for the Olympics in northern Italy, which begin on February 6. “My day-to-day life as an athlete hasn’t changed a whole lot,” he says. “But mentally, it’s quite different. I feel like there’s more purpose when I’m away. “I’m not doing it just for me.” Matt Graham during moguls qualfying at the 2022 Beijing Games. Credit: Getty Graham and his partner Jess had daughter Ada in September 2024 and were married 13 months later in October last year.

Advertisement

“It was a big step, obviously,” he says. “Anyone who’s a parent sort of knows that the transition can be quite full on. But yeah, I mean, Jess and I were both ready to become parents. “We’d obviously spoken about it a lot, leading up to us trying to be parents, and then once it eventually happened, it was about preparing for the hard times when I was going to be away.” Graham had a patchy season last year. But he bounced back in sparkling fashion last month, winning a World Cup moguls event in Ruka, Finland. It was a unique double for Australia as Jakara Anthony also won gold. “My performances in the past season were, it was a bit of a rocky road,” Graham says. “But the failures, or the times I didn’t succeed on the competition tour, it made it easier to get over because I would just go home and get Jess on FaceTime and, I mean, yeah, my daughter, Ada, she doesn’t care.

Advertisement

“She’s just smiling and yapping away. So it makes that easier to sort of push past and move on from those downtimes.” Graham hit a low point in December 2021. Coming off an Olympic silver medal in South Korea in 2018, he broke his collarbone in a heavy fall in Sweden just two months out from the 2022 Olympics in Beijing. Despite an intensive rehabilitation program, he was far from his best. He competed in pain and finished 29th. Matt Graham during moguls qualifying at the 2022 Olympics in Beijing. Credit: Getty The experience rocked Graham. He admits he was “heartbroken” and considered calling time on his career. But the qualified civil engineer made some adjustments and rediscovered his love of the sport before he had to overcome more setbacks. His collarbone hadn’t healed properly, and he was sent for further surgery. “Generally speaking, a broken collarbone is an easy injury to come back from, but unfortunately, mine was a little bit more complicated,” Graham told the NSW Institute of Sport.

Advertisement

“I had some issues with the bone healing. Consequently, I had to undergo four completely separate surgeries, which prolonged the injury over a two-year period.” After the operations and three sets of plates and screws, Graham then had to rediscover the right mindset. “Sometimes, you know, you’ll have a big crash, a big stumble, and you’ve got to get back up and right your wrong, and learn from that mistake,” he says. “I guess I’ve developed a bit of a way to push past those things and just know that I’ll be fine. If I attack a course, and I’m hesitant or conservative, then I’m at more risk than if I more or less just attack it. “Sometimes a moguls course can be pretty daunting, it can be steep, it can be icy, in some cases it can be a little bit scary. So, I guess you have to have a screw or two loose to take that step and really attack each day in each competition. “[But] I’d say generally I’m quite conservative in life. The risks we do out in the snow, they’re very calculated.

title: ASX higher as energy shares shine; The Star stumbles
text:
Advertisement

Updated BusinessMarketsWorld markets ASX higher as energy shares shine; The Star stumbles Staff reporter Updated January 30, 2026 — 1:20pm ,first published January 30, 2026 — 5:23am Save You have reached your maximum number of saved items. Remove items from your saved list to add more. Save this article for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime. Got it Share A A A

Energy shares gained ground on the Australian sharemarket after oil prices jumped again following a dramatic day on Wall Street where investors wiped $US357 billion ($506 billion) off Microsoft’s market capitalisation. The S&P/ASX 200 was up 22.1 points, or 0.3 per cent, to 894961 in early trade, with seven of 11 industry sectors in the green. Technology shares are the heaviest weight on the index. Company results have had a lot of influence on Wall Street’s direction this week. Bloomberg Energy stocks jumped as oil prices rose on worries tension between the United States and Iran could constrict the flow of crude. Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth warned the US military “will be prepared to deliver whatever the president expects,” just a day after President Donald Trump told Iran to “make a deal” on its nuclear program. Woodside Energy advanced 1 per cent and Santos gained 3.1 per cent in early afternoon trade. Shares in embattled gaming company The Star erased early gains to slump 11 per cent lower in early afternoon trade. In a quarterly update, the company posted $301 million revenue in the December quarter, a 6 per cent rise over the prior quarter, but warned of “numerous material” uncertainties.

Advertisement

Local tech shares suffered losses echoing a difficult night on Wall Street for tech giants following Microsoft’s 10 per cent tumble. WiseTech fell 1.6 per cent, Xero lost 1.4 per cent and Technology One retreated 2.2 per cent. Gold stocks retreated after the price of the safe haven metal fell sharply overnight. Gold, near $US5600 an ounce, suddenly and briefly dropped below $US5200 before advancing again to fetch around $US5427 at 10.36am AEDT. In early trade, Northern Star added 0.7 per cent, Evolution Mining fell 0.8 per cent and Newmont slipped 2.9 per cent. Among the iron ore heavyweights, BHP advanced 0.8 per cent, Rio Tinto added 0.6 per cent and Fortescue lost 1 per cent. Bank stocks are mixed. Westpac climbed 0.8 per cent in early afternoon trade, ANZ Bank added 0.5 per cent, National Australia Bank edged up 0.2 per cent while Commonwealth Bank dipped 0.1 per cent. Nine Entertainment, owner of this masthead, added 4.1 per cent after it struck a deal to sell Australia’s top-rating conservative talkback stations 2GB, 3AW, 4BC and 6PR to publican and pokies billionaire Arthur Laundy and his family for $56 million. Nine has also purchased outdoor media firm QMS for $850 million.

Advertisement

The Australian dollar was trading at US70.14¢ at 12.24pm AEDT. Related Article Opinion

Federal Reserve Trump will be seeing red as the Fed refuses to bow down Stephen Bartholomeusz Senior business columnist Overnight, the S&P 500 slipped 0.1 per cent after flirting with its record high in the morning and dropping by as much as 1.5 per cent later in the day. The Dow Jones rose 55 points, or 0.1 per cent, after erasing an earlier loss of more than 400 points, and the Nasdaq composite fell 0.7 per cent. Microsoft was the heaviest weight on Wall Street by far. The tech giant plunged amid scepticism over how much the company is investing in artificial intelligence, despite reporting stronger profit and revenue for the latest quarter than analysts expected. It was the stock’s worst day since the market’s COVID-19 crash in 2020.

Advertisement

Apple’s iPhone sales soared to a new quarterly record during the holiday season, despite artificial intelligence blunders that prompted the technology trendsetter to get a helping hand from Google. Shares are up 1 per cent in after-hours trading. Microsoft tumbled 10 per cent with concerns rising about how much the company is investing in AI. Bloomberg Tesla weighed on the market after falling 3.5 per cent. It delivered a bigger profit for the latest quarter than analysts expected, but the results were sharply lower than from a year earlier. Tesla’s leader, Elon Musk, has been trying to get investors to focus less on its flagging car sales and more on the company’s robotaxis and robots. Companies across the market are under pressure to deliver at least solid growth in profits following record-setting runs for their stock prices. Stock prices tend to follow the path of corporate profits over the long term, and earnings need to rise to quiet criticism that stocks have grown too expensive. Still, more stocks rose within the S&P 500 than fell. Leading them was Meta Platforms, which rallied 10.4 per cent after the company behind Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp topped profit expectations, even though it also said it will continue its massive investments in AI. IBM was another winner and climbed 5.1 per cent after surpassing analysts’ expectations for profit and revenue.

Advertisement

Related Article Opinion

AI Robots, redundancies and runaway spending: Not all AI hits the mark Elizabeth Knight Business columnist Some of the wildest action in financial markets was again for precious metals. Silver, which has been zooming higher in its own feverish run, had a similar and sudden reversal of momentum before ticking higher again. Bitcoin, which is pitched as a form of “digital gold”, also fell sharply. It sank nearly 6 per cent and dropped toward $US84,000. On the bond market, the yield on the 10-year Treasury dipped to 4.23 per cent from 4.26 per cent late on Wednesday. With AP The Market Recap newsletter is a wrap of the day’s trading.
